results.name: Number of ordered ways to write n = x^2 + y*(y+1) + z*(z^2+1), where x, y and z are nonnegative integers.
comment: Conjecture: a(n) > 0 for all n = 0,1,2,..., and a(n) = 1 only for n = 0, 1, 5, 7, 19, 35, 54, 62, 63, 197, 285, 339, 479, 505, 917. Moreover, any integer n > 2 can be written as x^2 + y*(y+1) + z*(z^2+1), where x is a positive integer, and y and z are nonnegative integers.

We also guess that each n = 0,1,2,... can be expressed as x*(x+1)/2 + P(y,z) with x, y and z nonnegative integers, where P(y,z) is any of the polynomials y(y+1) + z^2*(z+1), y^2 + z*(z^2+2), y^2 + z*(z^2+7), y^2 + z*(z^2+z+2), y^2 + z*(z^2+2z+3), y^2 + z*(2z^2+z+1).
It is known that every n = 0,1,2,... can be written as x^2 + y*(y+1) + z*(z+1), where x, y and z are nonnegative integers.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
